title: ‘The NEW French franc’ Le Pen set to 'BREAK UP the euro & restore national currencies’
text:
‘The NEW French franc’ Le Pen set to 'BREAK UP the euro & restore national currencies’ ‘The NEW French franc’ Le Pen set to 'BREAK UP the euro & restore national currencies’ MARINE Le Pen will urge European leaders to ditch the euro and return to national currencies if she wins the French president election in May, her chief economic adviser has claimed. PUBLISHED: 03:06, Wed, Feb 8, 2017 | UPDATED: 04:09, Wed, Feb 8, 2017 GETTY Marine Le Pen is calling for a return to national currencies amid fears for the euro's future 
With a “return to monetary sovereignty” a key pledge in Le Pen’s campaign, the National Front leader is promising to call a summit of EU leaders and the European Central Bank (ECB) where she plans to push for eurozone members to replace the single currency. 
In its place would be a basket of new national currencies, similar to the European Currency Unit which was the unit of account of the European Community before it was replaced by the euro in 1999. Related articles ‘Swiss franc ON STEROIDS’ Pound SURGE predicted 
The weighting of each currency would be fixed as a percentage in line with each country’s share in the EU’s gross product and its internal trade. 
National Front MP Bernard Monot believes the currency would be called the “new French franc” and it would equivalent to the euro when it is launched. Get to know Marine Le Pen Sat, January 28, 2017 Marine Le Pen is a French politician who is the president of the National Front, a national-conservative political party in France and one of its main political forces. AFP/Getty Images 1 of 10 A French politician who is the president of the National Front (FN), a national-conservative political party in France and one of its main political forces. 
Monot claimed France would limit the new currency fluctuations against the EU currency basket to a maximum of 20 per cent, although he believes movement up to 10 per cent would be more realistic. 
While Le Pen’s currency plans have attracted some criticism, Monot believes it will be a step forward for France. 
He said: “I don’t think it will be a catastrophe because France is after all a major country and people will understand soon enough that we are working as patriots to restore France’s sovereignty. GETTY The French franc (pictured) was replaced by the euro in 1999 
“If there is a catastrophe, I have a plan - it’s in here”, he added, pointing to his head. 
Among the critics is Samy Chaar, chief economist at Banque Lombard Odier & Cie in Geneva, who disagrees with Monot view that switching currencies would result in a devaluation which would provide a quick boost to the French economy. GETTY Bernard Monot is one of Le Pen's leading advisers 
Mr Chaar said: “A dual currency system has never worked in the past. 
“The strong currency will be hoarded while the weak currency will be spent and lose its value, making it difficult for the Bank of France to maintain the peg.” Related articles
